questions.stem: In the Strange Situation, a 14-month-old becomes very upset when the mother leaves the room. Upon reunion, the child reaches out to be picked up but then immediately pushes away and cries harder, alternating between clinging and angry resistance. This pattern is most consistent with which attachment classification?

options.text: Secure attachment (Type B)
Insecure-avoidant attachment (Type A)
Insecure-resistant/ambivalent attachment (Type C)
Disorganized/disoriented attachment (Type D)

questions.explanation: The pattern of simultaneously seeking and resisting contact, combined with difficulty being soothed, is the hallmark of insecure-resistant (ambivalent) attachment (Type C). These infants show heightened distress upon separation and are difficult to comfort upon reunion, reflecting an internal working model based on inconsistent caregiver responsiveness. Secure infants seek contact and are quickly soothed. Avoidant infants ignore or avoid the caregiver. Disorganized infants show contradictory, freezing, or fearful behaviors.

questions.stem: A parent describes their 6-month-old as fussy, with unpredictable eating and sleeping schedules, and intense emotional reactions to new situations. Using Thomas and Chess's classification, this infant would be described as having which temperament type?

options.text: Easy temperament
Difficult temperament
Slow-to-warm-up temperament
Behaviorally inhibited temperament

questions.explanation: Thomas and Chess classified the 'difficult' child (~10% of infants) as showing negative mood, irregular biological rhythms, slow adaptation to new experiences, and intense emotional reactions. This contrasts with the 'easy' child (positive mood, regular rhythms, adaptable) and the 'slow-to-warm-up' child (initially negative but low intensity, gradual adaptation). Behavioral inhibition is Jerome Kagan's construct, not Thomas and Chess's.

questions.stem: A researcher hides a toy under blanket A several times, and the 9-month-old successfully retrieves it each time. Then, in full view of the infant, the researcher hides the toy under blanket B. The infant searches under blanket A. This error is known as:

options.text: Failure of conservation
The A-not-B error
Centration on a single dimension
Deferred imitation failure

questions.explanation: The A-not-B error is a hallmark finding of Piaget's substage 4 (coordination of secondary schemes, 8-12 months). The infant perseverates in searching at the original location (A) even after watching the object being moved to a new location (B). This reflects immature object representation. Conservation failure is a preoperational error. Centration involves focusing on one perceptual dimension. Deferred imitation emerges around 18-24 months.

questions.stem: A 2-year-old says 'I goed to the park' even though no adult has ever modeled this sentence. This error provides the strongest evidence for which theoretical perspective on language acquisition?

options.text: Skinner's behaviorist account emphasizing reinforcement and imitation
Chomsky's nativist theory proposing an innate Language Acquisition Device
Bruner's interactionist account emphasizing social scaffolding
Vygotsky's sociocultural theory emphasizing the zone of proximal development

questions.explanation: Overregularization errors (e.g., 'goed,' 'mouses') are key evidence for Chomsky's nativist theory because they demonstrate that children are applying internalized grammatical rules rather than simply imitating adult speech. No adult models 'goed,' so the child must have extracted the past-tense rule (verb + '-ed') and applied it to an irregular verb. This creative, rule-governed production cannot be explained by imitation or reinforcement alone, which is Skinner's framework.

questions.stem: A clinician notes that a child adopted from an institution at 18 months shows contradictory reunion behaviors including approaching the caregiver while looking away, freezing mid-movement, and displaying fearful expressions. According to Main and Solomon, this pattern is classified as:

options.text: Secure attachment with mild separation anxiety
Insecure-avoidant attachment
Insecure-resistant/ambivalent attachment
Disorganized/disoriented attachment (Type D)

questions.explanation: Disorganized/disoriented attachment (Type D), identified by Mary Main and Judith Solomon, is characterized by contradictory behaviors (approaching while looking away), freezing, apprehension, and lack of a coherent strategy for managing distress. It is often associated with frightening or frightened caregiver behavior and maltreatment. Type D carries the highest risk for later psychopathology, including dissociative symptoms, borderline personality features, and externalizing problems.

questions.stem: A developmental psychology student is reviewing Bowlby's ethological attachment theory. Which of the following are accurate about Bowlby's model? Select all that apply.

options.text: Attachment is an evolved behavioral system designed to maintain proximity between infants and caregivers
Early attachment experiences create internal working models of self and others that guide later relationships
Clear-cut attachment emerges at birth with immediate stranger anxiety
Separation anxiety and use of the caregiver as a secure base emerge during the clear-cut attachment phase (6-8 to 18 months)
Bowlby proposed four phases of attachment development from birth through toddlerhood

questions.explanation: Bowlby proposed attachment as an evolved system for proximity maintenance, that internal working models guide later relationships, and four developmental phases. Clear-cut attachment (6-8 to 18 months) is when separation and stranger anxiety emerge, not at birth. The pre-attachment phase (birth to 6 weeks) involves indiscriminate social responsiveness without specific attachment.

questions.stem: A clinician is reviewing the developmental significance of disorganized (Type D) attachment. Which of the following statements are accurate? Select all that apply.

options.text: Disorganized attachment was identified by Mary Main and Judith Solomon as an addition to Ainsworth's original three categories
It carries the highest risk for later psychopathology among attachment classifications
It is associated with dissociative symptoms, borderline personality features, and externalizing problems
It represents the most common attachment pattern, found in approximately 60% of infants
It is often linked to frightening or frightened caregiver behavior and histories of maltreatment

questions.explanation: Disorganized attachment (Type D) was added by Main and Solomon (1986) and is found in approximately 5-10% of infants (not 60%; secure attachment is the most common at ~60-65%). It carries the highest psychopathology risk, is associated with dissociative symptoms, borderline features, and externalizing problems, and is linked to frightening/frightened caregiver behavior and maltreatment.

questions.stem: A speech-language pathologist is evaluating a toddler's language development. Which of the following milestones are correctly matched to their typical age of emergence? Select all that apply.

options.text: Cooing (vowel-like sounds) emerges around 0-2 months
Babbling (consonant-vowel combinations) emerges around 4-6 months
First words typically appear around 12 months
Telegraphic speech (two-word combinations) typically emerges around 6-8 months
The vocabulary spurt occurs around 18-24 months with rapid word acquisition

questions.explanation: Cooing emerges around 0-2 months, babbling around 4-6 months, first words around 12 months, and the vocabulary spurt with telegraphic speech around 18-24 months. Telegraphic speech (two-word combinations like 'mommy go') emerges around 18-24 months, not 6-8 months. At 6-8 months, infants are in the babbling stage.

questions.stem: A developmental neuroscience course covers brain development in the first two years. Which of the following are accurate? Select all that apply.

options.text: The infant brain doubles in weight by the first birthday
Synaptic pruning eliminates underused connections based on environmental input
Motor milestones follow a cephalocaudal (head-to-toe) and proximodistal (center-to-periphery) pattern
Myelination is complete by 6 months of age
Experience-expectant development requires typical environmental input such as visual stimulation and language exposure

questions.explanation: The infant brain doubles in weight by age 1 and reaches ~75% of adult size by age 2. Synaptic pruning eliminates underused connections following 'use it or lose it' principles. Motor development follows cephalocaudal and proximodistal patterns. Myelination continues well into adolescence and early adulthood, not completing by 6 months. Experience-expectant development requires species-typical environmental input for normal neural development.

questions.stem: A professor is discussing Chomsky's nativist arguments for innate language capacity. Which of the following are key nativist arguments? Select all that apply.

options.text: The poverty of the stimulus argument: language input is too incomplete to account for children's grammatical knowledge
Overregularization errors like 'goed' demonstrate rule extraction rather than imitation
All human languages share deep structural features, suggesting a Universal Grammar
Language learning is best explained by reinforcement of successive approximations
There is a biologically determined sensitive period for language acquisition

questions.explanation: Key nativist arguments include the poverty of the stimulus (input too impoverished for complex grammar), overregularization (evidence of rule extraction), Universal Grammar (shared deep structure across languages), and a biological sensitive period for language. The claim that language is learned through reinforcement of successive approximations is Skinner's behaviorist position, which Chomsky explicitly rejected.

questions.stem: Match each attachment classification with the characteristic reunion behavior observed in the Strange Situation.

columns.text: Seeks contact, quickly soothed, returns to play
Ignores or avoids caregiver; shows minimal distress
Clings and resists simultaneously; difficult to soothe

questions.explanation: Secure (Type B) infants seek contact and are quickly soothed upon reunion. Avoidant (Type A) infants ignore or avoid the caregiver and show minimal distress. Resistant/Ambivalent (Type C) infants simultaneously cling to and resist the caregiver, remaining difficult to soothe. Disorganized (Type D) infants show contradictory, freezing, or fearful behaviors, lacking a coherent coping strategy.

questions.stem: Match each language acquisition theorist with their primary proposed mechanism for language learning.

columns.text: Operant conditioning: reinforcement, shaping, and imitation
Innate Language Acquisition Device (LAD) with Universal Grammar
Language Acquisition Support System (LASS) through social scaffolding
General cognitive abilities (pattern recognition, intention-reading) in social contexts

questions.explanation: Skinner proposed language is learned through operant conditioning principles. Chomsky argued for an innate LAD containing Universal Grammar. Bruner proposed the LASS, emphasizing that social interaction scaffolds language learning (complementing Chomsky's LAD). Tomasello argued children learn language through general cognitive abilities like pattern recognition and intention-reading applied within social interactions.

questions.stem: For each attachment classification, select ALL caregiver characteristics and outcomes that apply.
questions.explanation: Secure attachment develops with sensitive, responsive, consistent caregiving. Insecure-avoidant attachment is associated with emotionally unavailable or rejecting caregivers. Insecure-resistant attachment develops with inconsistently responsive caregivers. Disorganized attachment carries the highest risk for later psychopathology and is associated with frightening or frightened caregiver behavior.

questions.stem: For each Piaget sensorimotor substage, select ALL cognitive achievements that first emerge during that substage.

columns.text: Actions producing effects on external environment

questions.explanation: Primary circular reactions (1-4 months) involve repetition of body-centered actions (e.g., thumb sucking). Secondary circular reactions (4-8 months) involve repeating actions that produce effects on the external environment. Coordination of secondary schemes (8-12 months) introduces intentional, goal-directed behavior. Mental representation (18-24 months) brings deferred imitation and symbolic thought.

questions.stem: Bowlby proposed that early attachment experiences create {{blank1}} of the self and others that guide relationship expectations throughout the lifespan. Mary Ainsworth developed the {{blank2}} paradigm to assess attachment quality. The most common attachment pattern is {{blank3}}, found in approximately 60-65% of infants. The attachment classification carrying the highest risk for later psychopathology is {{blank4}}.

options.text: internal working models
schemas of equilibration
behavioral reinforcement patterns
ecological system maps
Visual Cliff
Strange Situation
Still Face
Social Referencing
insecure-avoidant (Type A)
insecure-resistant (Type C)
secure (Type B)
disorganized (Type D)
secure (Type B)
insecure-avoidant (Type A)
insecure-resistant (Type C)
disorganized (Type D)

questions.explanation: Bowlby proposed internal working models as mental representations of self and others formed through early attachment experiences. Ainsworth developed the Strange Situation paradigm. Secure attachment (Type B) is the most common (~60-65%). Disorganized attachment (Type D) carries the highest risk for psychopathology, including dissociative symptoms and borderline personality features.

questions.stem: Thomas and Chess identified three temperament types based on the New York Longitudinal Study. The {{blank1}} child shows positive mood, regular rhythms, and easy adaptability, comprising about 40% of their sample. They introduced the concept of {{blank2}} to describe the match between a child's temperament and environmental demands. Jerome Kagan's research on {{blank3}} identified a biologically based tendency toward wariness of novelty, found in approximately 15-20% of infants, which is associated with later {{blank4}}.

options.text: easy
difficult
slow-to-warm-up
securely attached
temperamental resilience
goodness of fit
behavioral inhibition
secure base phenomenon
the easy temperament
goodness of fit
behavioral inhibition
disorganized attachment
conduct disorder
social anxiety
oppositional defiant disorder
autism spectrum disorder

questions.explanation: The 'easy' child (~40%) shows positive mood, regularity, and adaptability. Thomas and Chess's concept of goodness of fit describes the match between temperament and environment. Kagan's behavioral inhibition is a biologically based wariness of novelty (15-20% of infants) associated with heightened risk for social anxiety disorder in later childhood and adolescence.

questions.stem: A pediatrician refers an 18-month-old to a developmental specialist. The child has not yet spoken any recognizable words, does not point to objects of interest, does not respond to her name, and shows limited eye contact with caregivers.

options.text: Absence of first words by 18 months (expected around 12 months)
Lack of joint attention behaviors including pointing and shared gaze
Normal cooing and babbling that simply plateaued
Age-appropriate social engagement with mild speech delay
Possible autism spectrum disorder requiring comprehensive evaluation
Normal developmental variation requiring no intervention
Simple expressive language delay with intact social communication
Formal developmental and hearing evaluation should be conducted
Early intervention services should be initiated regardless of final diagnosis
Recommend waiting until age 3 before any evaluation
Reassure parents that the child will likely catch up without intervention

questions.explanation: The combination of absent first words by 18 months and lack of joint attention behaviors (pointing, shared gaze, eye contact) raises concern for autism spectrum disorder. These are not simply language delays but involve deficits in social communication. Appropriate next steps include formal developmental and hearing evaluation and early intervention services, as early intervention maximizes developmental outcomes regardless of final diagnosis.

questions.stem: A clinician is working with parents of a 4-month-old who describe their infant as extremely reactive to novel stimuli, crying intensely in unfamiliar environments, and showing high physiological arousal (elevated heart rate) when exposed to new people or situations.

options.text: High reactivity and wariness in response to novel stimuli
Elevated physiological arousal (heart rate) to unfamiliar situations
Positive approach behavior and curiosity toward new experiences
Irregular biological rhythms and intense negative mood
Behavioral inhibition as described by Jerome Kagan
Difficult temperament as described by Thomas and Chess
Insecure-resistant attachment
Heightened risk for developing social anxiety disorder in childhood
Importance of goodness of fit between temperament and parenting approach
The child will inevitably develop an anxiety disorder
Behavioral inhibition typically resolves completely by age 2

questions.explanation: The pattern of high reactivity and physiological arousal to novelty describes Kagan's behavioral inhibition. This is distinct from Thomas and Chess's 'difficult' temperament (which emphasizes irregular rhythms and negative mood broadly, not specifically novelty wariness). Behavioral inhibition carries heightened risk for social anxiety, but it does not inevitably lead to a disorder. Goodness of fit between temperament and parenting is clinically important.

questions.stem: A student is reviewing Piaget's sensorimotor stage for the EPPP. Highlight ALL accurate statements.
questions.passage: Object permanence is fully established at birth, allowing neonates to search for hidden objects. [Object permanence begins to emerge around 4-8 months and is fully developed by 18-24 months]. The A-not-B error occurs when an infant correctly searches at the new hiding location. [The A-not-B error involves the infant perseverating at the original location A, even after watching the object being moved to location B]. Deferred imitation, the ability to reproduce a behavior observed at an earlier time, emerges during the primary circular reactions substage. [Deferred imitation emerges during the mental representation substage (18-24 months), marking the transition to symbolic thought]. Secondary circular reactions involve repetition of body-centered actions such as thumb sucking. [Secondary circular reactions (4-8 months) involve repeating actions that produce interesting effects on the external environment, not body-centered actions]. The sensorimotor stage spans from birth to approximately age 7.

highlightableSegments.text: Object permanence begins to emerge around 4-8 months and is fully developed by 18-24 months
The A-not-B error involves the infant perseverating at the original location A, even after watching the object being moved to location B
Deferred imitation emerges during the mental representation substage (18-24 months), marking the transition to symbolic thought
Secondary circular reactions (4-8 months) involve repeating actions that produce interesting effects on the external environment, not body-centered actions

questions.explanation: All four bracketed statements are correct. Object permanence develops gradually (4-8 months to 18-24 months). The A-not-B error involves perseveration at the original location. Deferred imitation emerges at 18-24 months during the mental representation substage. Secondary circular reactions involve external effects, while primary circular reactions are body-centered. The unbracketed incorrect statements claim object permanence is present at birth, that the A-not-B error involves correct searching, and that the sensorimotor stage spans to age 7 (it spans to age 2).

questions.stem: A student is reviewing language acquisition theories. Highlight ALL accurate statements.
questions.passage: Skinner's Verbal Behavior proposed that language is acquired through innate grammatical structures. [Skinner argued language is acquired through operant conditioning principles including reinforcement, shaping, and imitation]. Chomsky agreed with Skinner that reinforcement is sufficient to explain language creativity. [Chomsky's 1959 review of Verbal Behavior argued that reinforcement cannot explain the speed, creativity, and rule-governed nature of language acquisition]. Chomsky proposed the concept of child-directed speech as the primary mechanism of language learning. [Chomsky proposed the Language Acquisition Device (LAD), an innate neurological mechanism containing Universal Grammar]. Bruner's LASS complemented Chomsky's LAD by emphasizing social scaffolding of language learning. [Overregularization errors like 'goed' and 'mouses' demonstrate that children extract grammatical rules rather than simply imitating adult speech]. The Skinner-Chomsky debate is considered one of the pivotal events in the cognitive revolution.

highlightableSegments.text: Skinner argued language is acquired through operant conditioning principles including reinforcement, shaping, and imitation
Chomsky's 1959 review of Verbal Behavior argued that reinforcement cannot explain the speed, creativity, and rule-governed nature of language acquisition
Chomsky proposed the Language Acquisition Device (LAD), an innate neurological mechanism containing Universal Grammar
Overregularization errors like 'goed' and 'mouses' demonstrate that children extract grammatical rules rather than simply imitating adult speech

questions.explanation: All four bracketed statements are accurate. Skinner proposed operant conditioning for language. Chomsky's 1959 review challenged this, arguing reinforcement is insufficient. Chomsky proposed the LAD with Universal Grammar. Overregularization is key evidence for rule extraction over imitation. The unbracketed incorrect statements claim Skinner proposed innate structures (he proposed conditioning), that Chomsky agreed with Skinner (he challenged him), and that Chomsky proposed child-directed speech (that is an interactionist concept).

questions.stem: Arrange the language development milestones in the correct chronological order from earliest to latest.

items.text: Cooing: Vowel-like sounds (0-2 months)
Babbling: Consonant-vowel combinations (4-6 months)
First words: Typically referential naming (approximately 12 months)
Holophrastic speech: Single words conveying whole sentences (12-18 months)
Vocabulary spurt and telegraphic speech: Two-word combinations (18-24 months)

questions.explanation: Language milestones follow a predictable sequence: Cooing (0-2 months) involves vowel-like sounds. Babbling (4-6 months) introduces consonant-vowel combinations. First words (approximately 12 months) are typically referential. Holophrastic speech (12-18 months) uses single words to convey complete thoughts. The vocabulary spurt and telegraphic speech (18-24 months) bring rapid word acquisition and two-word combinations.

questions.stem: Arrange Bowlby's four phases of attachment development in the correct chronological order.

items.text: Pre-attachment: Indiscriminate social responsiveness (birth to 6 weeks)
Attachment-in-the-making: Differential responding to familiar caregivers (6 weeks to 6-8 months)
Clear-cut attachment: Separation anxiety, stranger anxiety, secure base behavior (6-8 months to 18 months)
Reciprocal relationship: Negotiating separations using language and cognition (18 months to 2+ years)

questions.explanation: Bowlby's four phases proceed in order: Pre-attachment (birth to 6 weeks) involves indiscriminate social signals. Attachment-in-the-making (6 weeks to 6-8 months) shows differential responding to familiar figures. Clear-cut attachment (6-8 to 18 months) is marked by separation and stranger anxiety with secure base behavior. Reciprocal relationship (18 months+) involves cognitive understanding of caregiver's goals and negotiating separations.

questions.stem: A developmental psychologist tracks vocabulary growth during the first three years of life in a longitudinal sample.
questions.question: What key developmental pattern do these data illustrate?

options.text: Receptive and expressive vocabulary develop at identical rates
Receptive vocabulary consistently exceeds expressive vocabulary, and both show accelerating growth especially around 18-24 months
Expressive vocabulary exceeds receptive vocabulary at all ages
Both vocabulary measures remain stable through the first three years

questions.explanation: The data illustrate two important patterns: (1) receptive vocabulary (comprehension) consistently exceeds expressive vocabulary (production) at every age, and (2) both show accelerating growth, particularly the vocabulary spurt around 18-24 months when expressive vocabulary increases rapidly from approximately 80 to 250 words. This gap between comprehension and production is a well-documented phenomenon in language development, and children understand far more words than they can produce.

questions.stem: A neuroscientist presents data on synaptic density in the prefrontal cortex across the first 20 years of life.
questions.question: What developmental process is best illustrated by the pattern of synaptic density shown in these data?

options.text: Synaptic density increases steadily throughout the first 20 years of life
Synaptic overproduction in early childhood followed by experience-dependent pruning that continues into adolescence
Synaptic density peaks at birth and declines immediately thereafter
Synaptic density remains constant from birth through adulthood

questions.explanation: The data show the well-documented pattern of synaptic overproduction (synaptogenesis) peaking around age 1, followed by gradual experience-dependent pruning that reduces synaptic density into adolescence and early adulthood. The brain produces far more synapses than it ultimately retains, and pruning eliminates underused connections, sculpting neural architecture based on environmental input. This 'use it or lose it' principle underscores the importance of enriched early environments.

questions.stem: Categorize each concept into the correct language acquisition theoretical perspective.

items.text: Verbal operants: mand, tact, echoic, intraverbal
Language Acquisition Device (LAD) and Universal Grammar
Language Acquisition Support System (LASS) through social routines
Poverty of the stimulus argument
Reinforcement and shaping of successive approximations
Child-directed speech (motherese/parentese) facilitating acquisition
Joint attention and intention-reading in social contexts

questions.explanation: Behaviorist (Skinner): Verbal operants (mand, tact, echoic, intraverbal) and reinforcement/shaping of speech. Nativist (Chomsky): LAD with Universal Grammar and the poverty of the stimulus argument. Interactionist: Bruner's LASS, child-directed speech (motherese), and Tomasello's emphasis on joint attention and intention-reading in social contexts.

questions.stem: Categorize each infant behavior or characteristic into its correct developmental domain.

items.text: Stranger anxiety and separation distress around 8 months
A-not-B error when searching for hidden objects
Holophrastic speech using single words to convey sentences
Using the caregiver as a secure base for exploration
Overextension of word meaning (calling all animals 'doggie')
Deferred imitation of a behavior observed at an earlier time
Telegraphic speech combining two content words

questions.explanation: Attachment & Social: Stranger/separation anxiety and secure base behavior are core attachment phenomena. Cognitive (Piaget): The A-not-B error and deferred imitation are sensorimotor stage achievements. Language: Holophrastic speech, overextension, and telegraphic speech are language development milestones in the first two years.
